knots.name: Square Knot
knots.description: A reliable binding knot that lies flat and won't slip when properly tied.

instructions.instruction: Hold one rope end in each hand. Cross the right rope over the left rope.
Bring the right rope under and up through the loop created.
Now cross the left rope over the right rope.
Bring the left rope under and up through the loop. Pull tight.

tips: Remember: Right over left, then left over right
Pull both ends evenly to tighten
The finished knot should lay flat

knots.name: Bowline
knots.description: Creates a secure loop that won't slip under load. Known as the 'king of knots'.

instructions.instruction: Create a small loop in the rope, leaving plenty of working end.
Pass the working end up through the loop from below.
Wrap the working end around the standing line.
Pass the working end back down through the original loop.
Tighten by pulling the working end and the loop.

tips: Remember: 'Up through the rabbit hole, around the tree, and back down the rabbit hole'
Always leave at least 6 inches of tail for safety
Check the knot before trusting it with your life

knots.name: Clove Hitch
knots.description: Quick and easy hitch for temporary attachment to poles or posts.

instructions.instruction: Wrap the rope around the post or pole.
Cross over and wrap around again.
Tuck the working end under the last wrap and pull tight.

knots.name: Figure Eight
knots.description: A stopper knot that's easy to untie even after being loaded.

instructions.instruction: Form a loop in the rope.
Pass the working end around and through the loop.
Tighten the knot by pulling both ends.

knots.name: Trucker's Hitch
knots.description: Powerful mechanical advantage knot for securing heavy loads.

instructions.instruction: Create a loop in the rope using a slip knot.
Pass the working end through the anchor point.
Thread the working end through the loop to create a pulley system.
Pull tight and secure with two half hitches.

knots.name: Sheet Bend
knots.description: Best knot for joining two ropes of different sizes or materials.

instructions.instruction: Form a loop with the thicker rope.
Pass the thinner rope up through the loop.
Wrap around both parts of the thick rope and back under itself.

knots.name: Prusik Knot
knots.description: Friction knot that grips under load but slides when unloaded.

instructions.instruction: Wrap the prusik cord around the main rope.
Pass the loop through itself and wrap again.
Tighten by pulling the loop away from the main rope.

knots.name: Half Hitch
knots.description: Simple hitch often used to finish other knots.

instructions.instruction: Pass the rope around the object.
Bring the working end over and under the standing line.

knots.name: Timber Hitch
knots.description: Specialized hitch for attaching rope to cylindrical objects.

instructions.instruction: Wrap the rope around the log or timber.
Twist the working end around itself several times.

knots.name: Butterfly Knot
knots.description: Creates a secure loop in the middle of a rope without accessing the ends.

instructions.instruction: Form a figure-8 loop in the rope.
Fold the top loop down over the crossing.
Pull the folded loop through and tighten.

knots.name: Rolling Hitch
knots.description: An adjustable hitch that grips well under tension and can slide when slack. Excellent for adjusting tension on guy lines.

instructions.instruction: Pass the working end around the standing line or object.
Make a second wrap around, staying on the loaded side.
Cross over and make a third wrap on the other side.
Finish with a half hitch to lock the knot in place.

tips: Keep the first two wraps on the side that will be loaded
The knot will grip when loaded but slide when slack
Great for adjusting tent guy lines without untying
Works best on smooth, round objects
